TEXT: The applicant is a citizen of GPE , born in DATE and living in GPE in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant brought proceedings against the local authority , the Southend on ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , in which he challenged a civil action brought by the ORG in connection with his barge . The action was compromised on DATE . Thereafter , in DATE , the ORG took possession of the barge and its contents , and sold them .

On DATE , the applicant issued a writ in which he claimed that the ORG was not entitled to sell the barge and contents , and had not properly accounted for the proceeds of sale . The writ was served on the ORG on DATE and a statement of claim was served on DATE . ORG responded with a Defence and Counterclaim , and PERSON and Better Particulars of LAW on DATE . The applicant served a Reply and Defence to Counterclaim and a Request for Further and Better Particulars of the Defence on DATE . On DATE he also supplied responses to the ORG ’s request for Particulars . Pleadings were deemed ( by the Rules of ORG ) to be closed in DATE . The applicant ’s summons for directions was issued on CARDINAL DATE and a hearing took place on DATE .

On the DATE the applicant issued a summons for specific discovery . On DATE the ORG issued a summons applying to strike out the applicant ’s claim for want of prosecution . The summonses were due to be heard together on DATE , but were adjourned due to lack of time .

In DATE the applicant took steps to have his summons restored for hearing . On DATE the applicant ’s summons was adjourned for DATE ; it was adjourned for a second time at the request of the parties from DATE to DATE .

On DATE a District Judge acceded to the ORG ’s submissions that the applicant had been guilty of inordinate and inexcusable delay , causing prejudice to the ORG , and he accordingly dismissed the applicant ’s claim .
The applicant appealed to ORG . The appeal was heard on DATE and the judge ’s order was sealed on DATE . The applicant ’s appeal was allowed and leave to appeal against the order was refused .

The ORG then applied to ORG for leave to appeal against the order . The ORG ’s application was rejected on the papers by Lord Justice PERSON on DATE , the decision being set out in an order dated DATE . The ORG therefore applied for , and secured , an oral hearing before ORG on DATE , at which hearing leave to appeal was granted .

The parties lodged bundles of documents for the appeal on DATE . The bundles were approved by ORG on DATE . There was subsequently a clarification of the law on dismissal for want of prosecution in a leading decision by ORG [ DATE ] CARDINAL AC CARDINAL ) . This led to the ORG amending its notice of appeal , and the appeal bundles were finalised by DATE .

On DATE the ORG ’s appeal was listed to be heard on CARDINAL - CARDINAL DATE . On the DATE ORG , relying upon the decision of ORG in Roebuck v Mungovin , allowed the ORG ’s appeal and dismissed the action for want of prosecution . The Master of the Rolls , Sir PERSON , who gave the leading judgment , referred to the “ regrettable lapse of time ” prior to the hearing of the appeal by ORG .

By a letter dated DATE , the applicant sought the leave of ORG to appeal to ORG . This was refused on DATE . The applicant then presented a petition for leave to appeal to ORG on DATE . The applicant failed to lodge the relevant documents with this appeal . The judicial office of ORG requested the documents of the applicant on DATE and again on DATE . On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s petition for leave .
